noun.description: A musical or vocal sound with reference to its pitch, quality, and strength.
examples: the piano tone appears monochrome or lacking in warmth

noun.description: The general character or attitude of a place, piece of writing, situation, etc.
examples: my friend and I lowered the tone with our oafish ways
there was a general tone of ill-concealed glee in the reporting

noun.description: A basic interval in classical Western music, equal to two semitones and separating, for example, the first and second notes of an ordinary scale (such as C and D, or E and F sharp); a major second or whole step.
The particular quality of brightness, deepness, or hue of a tint or shade of a color.
examples: stained glass in vivid tones of red and blue
an attractive color that is even in tone and texture

noun.description: (in some languages, such as Chinese) a particular pitch pattern on a syllable used to make semantic distinctions.
The normal level of firmness or slight contraction in a resting muscle.

verb.description: Give greater strength or firmness to (the body or a part of it)
Harmonize with (something) in terms of color.
examples: the rich orange color of the wood tones beautifully with the yellow roses

verb.description: Give (a monochrome picture) an altered color in finishing by means of a chemical solution.

phrases: The synths had been toned down, replaced with tired guitar sounds.
Susan picked this colour for the walls, and toned it down with white to produce the shade she wanted, and the result is admirable.
We have gone away from the bright colour scheme and toned it down slightly.
Coat lipstick with a darker lip gloss to tone it down.
Would it really have detracted if the big keyboard synth sounds had been toned down to a minimum?
origin: Middle English: from Old French ton, from Latin tonus, from Greek tonos tension, tone, from teinein to stretch.
